description: CREATE Paisley (CREATE) is an innovative youth project in Renfrewshire which seeks to see ‘young people transformed through creativity, community, confidence and finding their voice’. CREATE works with young people, primarily ages 12-21, through drop ins, arts workshops, youth voice and activism, arts and wellbeing, mentoring and much more across key areas in Paisley, Johnstone, Linwood and throughout Renfrewshire. CREATE’s work is supported by a management team, a trained youth work team, artists and creatives, a dedicated team of volunteers and a number of key partners and funders. Find out more at: www.createpaisley.org.uk.

Ardgowan Hospice is a compassionate place of care for people living in Inverclyde who have been diagnosed with a life limiting illness, such as cancer, heart failure, lung disease, kidney failure or neurological conditions.

Making patients, families and carers feel at ease is one of the first things we do at Ardgowan Hospice.

location.address: Haghill Park Primary School 415 Cumbernauld Road

description:
Community on Solid Ground is an active and effective charity that uses sports, education, training, social activities, and mentoring to empower young people to increase their confidence, motivation, skills, employability and quality of life. All of CSG’s work is underpinned by the determination to improve the quality of life in the local community, addressing four key indicators:Health and Wellbeing

CSG combats health issues, such as adolescent depression and obesity, by increasing regular participation in sports activities. By offering healthy eating and cooking workshops and debates on lifestyle choices, we aim to instil positive behaviour leading to long-term healthy lifestyles for our service users.

location.address: Manley Park Community Centre, York Avenue, Whalley Range
Walford Mill, Knobcrook Rd, Stone Lane

description:
What does Citizens Advice do? Our Aims & Principles

Citizens Advice gives independent, impartial, free and confidential information and advice to help people overcome the problems they face, such as benefits, debt, employment, housing, relationships and immigration.

We use our knowledge about our clients’ problems to identify trends and campaign to improve the policies and practices that affect peoples’ lives.

The Citizens Advice service has 22,000 trained volunteers and 7,000 paid staff in 284 local Citizens Advice across England and Wales who provide an advice service to over 2.6 million people a year in over 2,500 locations in a range of ways including face to face, over the phone, by email and web-chat.

What happens at Citizens Advice Sheffield?

Citizens AdviceSheffield is part of the Citizens Advice network.

We are one of the country’s largest Citizens Advice delivering advice and advocacy services to over 27,000 people a year. We deliver services by phone, digitally and face to face, from multiple locations, to some of Sheffield’s most vulnerable communities.

Warrington BID covers the town centre and Stadium Quarter it is bounded by Mersey St, Wilson Pattern St Parker St and the Halliwell Jones Stadium.. It represents over 250 businesses spread across 300 commercial properties. We are a partnership between the businesses in the town centre. We work strategically with key organisations including Warrington and Co, Cheshire Police and Warrington Borough Council. 

Our BID members are diverse and include those from the private, public and voluntary sectors.

Since being established in 2018, it has worked to a business agenda and delivered programme of works to help make the town centre a more attractive and safer place to visit. It organises and promotes events and markets the town centre as a shopping and leisure destination

We exist to help businesses in the town centre to sustainably grow and progress.

What we do and who we care for

Founded in 1905 by the Sisters of Charity, St Joseph’s Hospice is one of the oldest and largest hospices in the UK. We provide, high quality, specialist palliative care and support to people in our local community who have a life-limiting illness. All our services are free of charge.

Our core boroughs are Newham, City and Hackney, Tower Hamlets and City and Hackney, Tower Hamlets and , but some of our services are also available to people in the surrounding boroughs of Waltham Forest, Islington, Haringey and Enfield reaching a population of around 2.1 million people.  

We take a holistic approach to our care, which means that we look after the wellbeing of the whole person, as well as their loved ones.  

We provide palliative care in the Hospice and in the community as we believe that people should choose where they receive their care. 

Our range of services include:


	Inpatient care
	Palliative care at home
	Community and day services
	Therapies
	Counselling and advice
	24 hour advice and support

description: The Holly Lodge Centre is an education charity in the heart of Richmond Park. We are a hidden treasure, with a beautiful 2 acre nature trail, a Victorian kitchen garden, large picnic garden and 2 Victorian classrooms. We provide learning to primary school children but also specialise in working with those with disabilites, young and old. We teach about plants, pond dipping and habitats, as well as gardening, life in Victorian times and art. Volunteering here is always different but always rewarding!

location.address: Abbotss Hall, Maldon Road, Great Wigborough
Unit 19, President Buildings, Savile Street East,

description:
Volunteers are essential to the work we do, providing help and support to vital services from socialising our puppies through to driving and working in the office.

If you would like to volunteer in any of the following areas below please fill in the application form by clicking Apply to volunteer

If you would like more information please select from the following or contact our Volunteer Coordinator, at volunteering@medicaldetectiondogs.org.uk or telephone 01296 655888

Regional Support Groups

Regional support groups are an essential part of Medical Detection Dogs. They can raise valuable funds and encourage local support as well as inspire others to help us. We are looking to establish a national network of groups.

What do groups do? Groups raise valuable funds for Medical Detection Dogs. Group members decide on ways to fundraise and organise their own events with support from Head Office or, where possible, Regional Fundraisers.

What is expected of a branch? Anything you raise is brilliant and valuable to the charity. The important thing is for each group to decide on an achievable goal and for everyone to enjoy what they are doing. As long as it is legal, have a go!

How many people make a support group? Fundraising can be hard work and it takes motivated and willing volunteers to set up a local fundraising group. Groups can vary in size and initiators can recruit as many or as few group members as they like, but really the more the better! If you are interested in or starting a joining a Regional support group please contact our Volunteer Coordinator Email volunteering@medicaldetectiondogs.org.uk or telephone 01296 655888

location.address: Galleon House Newby Road Industrial Estate
Orchard Brae House, 30 Queensferry Road, Edinburgh, EH4 2HS

description:
RYTC is a creative organisation that supports children, young people, and families through the power of drama, storytelling, and creative arts. We provide accessible, wellbeing-focused programmes that build confidence, connection, and emotional expression in safe, nurturing environments.

Our work includes drama workshops, creative learning projects, community events, and partnerships that celebrate inclusion, resilience, and personal growth. We believe every child and young person deserves to be seen, heard, and supported — and that creativity is a powerful tool for wellbeing and positive change.

RYTC works closely with Education Selection Box  to co-create opportunities that inspire young people and strengthen local communities across Warwickshire and the surrounding areas.

description: These are the volunteering opportunities for East Ham Library.

location.address: The Old School House, Blaxhall, Woodbridge, Suffolk

description:
Voluntary Action Islington (VAI) is the umbrella body for Islington’s diverse Voluntary, Community, Faith, and Social Enterprise (VCFSE) sector and has been providing infrastructure support services in the borough for over 50 years.

We offer a wide range of services for local organisations, small groups, and volunteers at all stages of their development. These services range from one-to-one support, through training and workshops.
We pride ourselves on excellence and quality, and we aim to lead and support a resilient local voluntary sector that actively collaborates to support residents and the community.

YHA Patterdale is located in the Lake District National Park, in the heart of the picturesque Ullswater Valley. We are at the foot of Helvellyn, England's third highest mountain and Ullswater is just a twenty minute walk away. There is some of the UK's best walking, canoeing, cycling and mountain biking to be found on our doorstep, and with a regular bus route between Penrith and Windermere you are never far from civilisation.

Built in the 1970s and with a unique look all of its own, this Scandinavian style rural retreat is lively, retro and full of character!

Whether you are looking to complete a hostel placement over several weeks or to take part in a volunteer working party or DofE residential event, we will help to make you feel welcome and part of the team. We love the help and support of our volunteers at YHA Patterdale so please, sign up!

Volunteering with YHA is a fantastic way to have fun, learn new skills, boost your CV and travel to different places. We have a variety of different opportunities to choose from and volunteering roles to suit everyone.  

The tasks are varied and in return you will meet some great people, who both work and stay in our hostels, as well as enjoying your time off discovering the local area and attractions.

Renfrewshire Council Youth Services deliver a range of youth work activities in schools and communities across Renfrewshire.

Our Service aim is to improve the outcomes for young people in Renfrewshire through youth work, youth information, empowerment activities and outdoor learning.

We work with young people aged 11 to 25 years old, and includes support for young people who experience challenges and are vulnerable and in need of additional support.

Our service activities include:


	Youth voice groups and empowerment programmes - where young people can have a say and lead on projects and campaigns that matter to them
	Peer led education - where young people can take a lead on youth consutlation and delivering training and information to their peers
	Young Scot and the National Entitlement Card in Renfrewshire - young people can take part in local and national inititatives, and collect rewards and experiences linked to the YS Card 
	Community based youth clubs - based in neighburhood community bases providing drop-in and clubs for young people on their door-step
	Access to youth information - finding out on opportunities for volunteering, and activites that can help connect young people to local and digital support services
	Outdoor learning activities - encouraging young people to take part in outdoor activites and promoting positive mental health and wellbeing
	Accredited awards and volunteering (e.g. Duke of Edinburgh's Award, Youth Achievement Awards)


Youth Services welcome anyone 16+yrs  who want to take on a volnteering role with us; this can include working alonside our youth workers to deliver activity programmes, in helping to plan and organise youth events to creating digital blogs and media.

Contact details: youth@renfrewshire.gov.uk

location.address: c/o West Primary School Newton Street

description:
YHA Streatley-on-Thames is a comfortable Victorian house five minutes' walk from one of the prettiest stretches of the River Thames. At the crossroads of the Thames Path and Ridgeway National Trails, and with National Trust woodlands behind the youth hostel, there are plenty of leisurely walks and cycle rides in the vicinity that our staff can tell you about.

We are close to Reading and Oxford for some city attractions and there is a direct train link to London.

Volunteering with YHA is a fantastic way to have fun, learn new skills, boost your CV and travel to different places. We have a variety of different opportunities to choose from and volunteering roles to suit everyone.  

The tasks are varied and in return you will meet some great people, who both work and stay in our hostels, as well as enjoying your time off discovering the local area and attractions.

We are Guide Dogs. And we’re here to help people with sight loss live the life they choose.

We rely on our brilliant volunteers who give their time to help our charity in so many ways. There are many great volunteering opportunities to get involved in, even an hour makes a big difference.

We recognise the extraordinary efforts of all of our volunteers and we're really proud to have achieved the Investing in Volunteers accreditation for good practice in volunteer management.

Together, we can help people affected by sight loss live their lives to the full.

location.address: Moss Side Millennium Powerhouse 140 Raby Street

description:
The University of East London offers students interested in game development:

You'll learn from a mix of academics and industry professionals with experience in game design and development. Industry speakers provide insights on various topics, keeping you up-to-date with the latest trends. Throughout the course, you'll create games for simulated real-world briefs. This hands-on approach allows you to develop games for different demographics, marketplaces, and player types, developing games in a studio environment!

Many UEL graduates have made their mark in the games industry. UEL offers three relevant programs, such as BA (Hons) Game Design, BSc (Hons) game programming and BA (Hons) 3D art for games which allow specialisation within the game design field- UEL equips you for a role in the expanding game industry.

Choose UEL for a dynamic learning experience that bridges theory and practice, preparing you for an exciting career in game development!

description:
IAPWA (International Aid for the Protection & Welfare of Animals) is a UK registered international animal welfare charity, dedicated to creating a better future for animals in need.

Our first project, established in 2009, was based in Sabah, Borneo, where we have provided a lifeline to thousands of dogs and cats in need of veterinary care and support. Our companion animal programmes have since developed in Penang Island and Romania.

Our passion for all animals has also seen us develop partnerships and campaigns to help other species. Wherever there is suffering, we aim to make a difference and with your support we can continue to protect and improve the welfare of animals worldwide.

The Neighbourhood health champions project is a partnership between the Manchester Local Care Organisation and the Moss Side Millennium Powerhouse. The aim of the project is to help improve health equity in the neighbourhood of Hulme, Moss Side and Rusholme in Manchester.

description:
About SeeSaw

SeeSaw provides grief support for children, young people and their families in Oxfordshire.  Through appropriate and timely support, SeeSaw can help to reduce the emotional, psychological and mental health consequences of bereavement.  Young people are then able to face the future with hope.

Our personal wellbeing services are available to male prison leavers and those on community orders aged 18 plus.

Our services are designed to help clients integrate into the communities by developing stronger, healthier relationships and interactions with family, friends and wider support networks.

We offer a range of one-to-one and group programmes and interventions including:


	Coaching and mentoring
	Partnerships and specialist legal advice holistically support clients’ wellbeing
	Social capital and personal development.

Heaton Moor RUFC is an inclusive community based rugby union club in South Manchester.  The club has three senior men's teams along with a thriving mini and junior section with 250 players from age 5 to 18.  The club is situated near Heaton Chapel station and is close to several main bus routes.  We provide various volunteering opportunities involving coaching mini and junior teams, refereeing and events management.  The club provides funding for all our volunteers to pursue RFU qualifications.  Our senior men's teams welcome all new players with any level of skill and experience.  We already have MMU students playing in our teams and provide a warm social welcome to new players.

description:
From Homelessness to Belonging.
Community-driven and innovative responses to homelessness and housing need

Protecting habitats, saving species and helping to end the nature and climate emergency.

Nature is in crisis. Together we can save it.

Jubilee Hospital Radio was established in 1977, the year of Queen Elizabeth II's Silver Jubilee. We commenced broadcasting a year later on the 25th June 1978, initially from two converted rooms at the former nurses home and we have been providing music and entertainment to the staff and patients of the Princess Elizabeth Hospital ever since. We were the Islands first local radio station until BBC local radio arrived in the Islands in 1982 followed by commercial radio ten years later in 1992.

description:
St Andrew’s First Aid is Scotland’s dedicated first aid charity and leading first aid training provider. We believe no one should suffer or die because they needed first aid and didn’t get it.

Our mission is to raise awareness of the importance of first aid skills through first aid event cover, first aid training courses and first aid education within schools and communities across Scotland.

description:
Lache Youth Club was started in November 2021, this is following a youth club shutting prior to Covid.

The newly established youth club is primary managed by Youth workers at St Marks Church and Sanctuary housing Youth worker, along with volunteers.

The youth club currently has approx 50 member aged between 7-11 years old.

We run on a Friday evening from 4.30-6pm.

The youth club has lots of different activities from, pool, dance, art & crafts, sports and lots of more, the young people whom attend are always interested in trying out new and exciting activities.

description: The British Red Cross helps millions of people in the UK and around the world get the support they need when crisis strikes. Whether you're affected by an emergency overseas or here at home, we provide guidance to help you know what to do before, during and after an emergency. Community Education is one way we support people by delivering workshops to community groups to give them skills to help them cope with an emergency.

description:
KEEN London is a small but growing charity. Our vision is that every child has the chance to enjoy games and leisure activities and none are left behind due to disability.

We support children, known as our ‘athletes’, with a wide range of additional needs, including autism, cerebral palsy, non-visible disabilities, and global development delay. You can expect to get involved with a wide range of playground games, ball games, nature walks, and creative activities. You’ll provide one-to-one support to an athlete, helping them to access all the activities on offer, achieve their personal development goals, and of course have tons of fun!

We are one of 4 charities that make up Carer Support Cumbria and we are a network partner of Carers Trust.

Renfrew YMCA is a locally based youth charity providing a needs led service for all young people of Renfrew, providing opportunities that due to deprivation, family circumstances and confidence they would not be able to undertake.  We pride our self on our YMCA family and ensure each young person feels included, respected and welcome.

description:
RUNFEST is an events management company, holding popular running races in Kew, Richmond and the Kingston area. We are small, family run company and love to provide our runners with a welcoming, fun and enjoyable exerience at our events. 

Any community events like ours cannot happen without the help of volunteers. Volunteer posts vary in time, so even if you have a couple of hours to offer we would love to have you!

Roles vary from welcome marshals, course marshals, baggage, water-station and finish line volunteers.

Once completed you will automatically be added to our volunteer list and we will be in touch to provide you with all the info you need. We will do our upmost best to allocate you the day and time of your choice.

description: At wishesjust4you, we believe in the power of kindness and the magic of dreams. Founded by Bill Stillman and a small group of compassionate individuals, our charity is dedicated to bringing light, joy, and unforgettable moments to children living with lifelong disabilities and life-limiting illnesses. From animal park visits to paragliding adventures, and Art Education, we’re here to turn wishes into realities

description:
Learn English at Home (LEAH) is a small charity helping refugees and migrants resident in the boroughs of Kingston, Richmond and Hounslow to improve their English language skills and become more active in their local community.
	We offer free 1 to 1 home-based English tuition and small group classes with creche facilities in the local community. Our service is provided for people who cannot otherwise attend classes by a team of highly-trained volunteer tutors.
	Our services offer clients a means to overcome isolation, increase confidence and gain knowledge of local services. They empower clients to become active members of society and in doing this; we contribute to building stronger communities.

location.address: Abraham Moss Centre, Level 2, Crescent Road

description:
About Us

Citizens Advice Carlisle & Eden offers free, confidential, independent, and impartial advice and information via a number of different channels (e.g. face-to-face, email, telephone) from our two main sites in Carlisle and Penrith and a number of outreach locations throughout the districts.

We provide the advice people need for the problems they face and campaign to improve the policies and practices that affect people’s lives.


“Citizens Advice Carlisle & Eden supports some of the most vulnerable people within our society. We provide information and advice to anyone in need and will always value diversity, promote equality and challenge discrimination.”

Andy Auld – Chief Executive


The Citizens Advice service values diversity, promotes equality and challenges discrimination.

We can help with housing and employment issues or deal with queries about consumer or tax issues.  We can advise on legal matters, answer questions about immigration and we have lots of experience on family and personal matters too.

Citizens Advice Carlisle & Eden is an independent, not-for-profit charity, supported by a range of different organisations, volunteers and paid staff without whom we would not be able to offer the quality service we do.

As a member of the Citizens Advice network we have access to an extensive information system which allows us to advise clients but also ensure the quality of our advice and training is the best around.


Our aims and principles

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a9wIbDNYoEY 

Citizens Advice Carlisle & Eden aims to:


	Provide the advice people need for the problems they face
	Improve the policies and practices that affect people’s lives


The Citizens Advice service provides free, independent, confidential and impartial advice to everyone on their rights and responsibilities.  We value diversity, promote equality and challenge discrimination.

St George's Centre, Altcar Rifle Range

description:
KEEN London is a small but growing charity. Our vision is that every child has the chance to enjoy games and leisure activities and none are left behind due to disability.


We provide free games and activity sessions with tailored support for children with additional needs and disabilities. We support over 100 children, known as our ‘athletes’, with a wide range of additional needs, including autism, cerebral palsy, learning disabilities, and global development delay. At KEEN London, we strive to use fun and games to improve young people's wellbeing, personal, social and emotional development as well as broadening experiences to increase skills and confidence.

For more information, please visit: https://www.keenlondon.org/ 

Or, you can keep up to date with KEEN London on Twitter, Facebook

KEEN London is a registered charity, number 1124915. It is also a limited company registered in England (number 6579658), and its registered office is:
Unit W1, 8 Woodberry Down, London, N4 2TG.

location.address: Golden Jubilee National Hospital Agamemnon Street

description:
Cabbage Hall CIC is a community allotment/garden which was formed in January 2020 in response to our vision to provide high quality, value for money services to a variety of groups and the general public. Assisting the community with socialising with like-minded people, supplying outdoor learning spaces for groups, young people and children within the community. Participants overall health improves whilst doing something worthwhile and productive which in turn lessens anxiety and depressive episodes, motivating them to have a purpose and feel useful and reintegrate back into society.

Activities at the community allotment fits in with the five ways to wellbeing


	Connect,
	Be active,
	Take Notice,
	Keep learning
	Give back.


An understanding of well-being encourages them to become more resilient in general, through active participation in the activities we have on offer. This includes Mindful Art / Craft making and sensory workshops / meditation. Up-cycling of wooden pallets turning them into planters and sold at a low cost along with bench making and hanging baskets. We invite partners in to do talks and workshops/ training around further development with a view to employment, training and volunteering. We also work with local schoolchildren to offer the opportunity to learn new skills in growing vegetables. We find that being involved in the outdoor allotment environment; individuals learn new skills around growing and caring for produce and then offered to the local community. Individuals include young people and their families who have the opportunity to connect with others and feel less isolated and make new friends and their wellbeing is greatly improved. Children can learn through play and benefit from being in the outdoors with hands on experience of growing food from seed to harvest watching them grow. A time for bonding outdoors.

location.address: Hard Lane, (Next to The Windle Pub)

description:
Finding Forever Homes since 1965 

We are here to take in pets that become homeless due to a change in circumstance

This can include pets that have been mistreated, neglected or abandoned. Regardless of their circumstance, each pet will find a warm bed, a kind team and all the love and respect they deserve awaiting them at Margaret Green Animal Rescue. We pride ourselves on the standard of care each rescue pet receives. As well as veterinary care, pets are prepared and rehabilitated ready for a new home. Most of our animals are vaccinated, microchipped, treated against worms and fleas and neutered before going to their new home.

Finding forever homes is at the very heart of what we do and there is no better feeling than knowing we have found the perfect match. Our rehoming process is designed specifically to help potential owners adopt a pet that fits in perfectly with their lives and loved ones. Animal welfare remains our priority with each decision made and we will always act in the animal’s best interest.  After adopting a pet from Margaret Green Animal Rescue, you can be assured that you will always have our support. For advice and guidance, we will be right beside you whenever you need us through the adoption process and onwards as you settle into a life together.

description:
One-Eighty is a mental health and behaviour support charity. We work across Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire, empowering children and young people to improve their mental health and re-engage with education.

Through intensive one-to-one sessions, we support children and young people dealing with complex personal challenges (such as trauma, bereavement, mental health difficulties, and those with difficult family circumstances) which prevent them from engaging with school.

We deliver preventative mental health projects to schools, and provide specialist training and support to professionals working with children and young people.

description:
Barnardo's is a British charity founded by Thomas John Barnardo in 1866, to care for vulnerable children and young people.It is the UK's largest children's charity.We protect, support and nurture the UK's most vulnerable children

We help hundreds of thousands of children, young people, parents and carers via our 800+ services across the UK.

Our amazing team of vibrant & diverse volunteers helps us run over 700 shops. Our stores sell lots of great donated & new goods to help raise vital funds to make a real difference to disadvantaged children, young people and families across the UK.

Our retail stores are the face of our charity on the high-street and in local communities. We have loads of amazing stock donated to us every week, and this all needs to be sorted, tagged and put on the shop-floor for sale!

location.address: Staffordshire Wildlife Trust The Wolseley Centre

description:
Refugee Education UK helps refugee and asylum-seeking children and young people build more hopeful futures through education.

REUK works with young people displaced by conflict or crisis and helps them get into, stay and thrive in education. We do this through three key programmes: educational mentoring, educational progression and wellbeing. REUK is also involved in research, consultancy, and advocacy, and runs training for practictioners.

The educational mentoring programme offers bespoke educational mentoring to young refugees, asylum seekers and survivors of trafficking across Oxford, London, the West Midlands and the East of England. This is the key area where REUK relies on volunteers, to support young people with 1:1 weekly sessions as their mentors.

How does mentoring work?

- REUK takes referrals of young people from schools and colleges, social services and a variety of other organisations and individuals
- We meet the young person for an initial assessment of their educational aspirations and current circumstances
- We match the individual young person with a trained, local volunteer mentor (this could be you!)
- The mentor meets the young person for an hour each week, in a public place, to support them towards their educational goal
- We ask for a minimum commitment of six month from both the young person and the mentor. After six months the relationship is reviewed to see if both mentor and mentee would like to continue
- The REUK local Mentoring Coordinator provides continued support to mentor and mentee all along their relationship

World Dodgeball Association, Wenlock Way Offices, Wenlock Way
Neston Community Youth Centre Ltd Burton Road

description: The idea of developing this project came from my clinical observation. I am a CBT therapist and a psychologist, and while treating people with depression, I have noticed that some people struggle to engage in pleasurable activities. The treatment for depression consists of engaging in pleasurable activities and cognitive restructuring. People struggle with the first part of the intervention because they don't like to do activities alone or don't know what they like. So, the idea of this project is to offer CBT sessions where people will learn how to moderate their mood. We will complement the therapy by offering a green space where they can access a wide range of pleasurable activities such as gardening, arts and crafts activities for the garden, building and creating things in the garden such as creating a fire pit, sitting areas, water features and lots more. On top of this, the participants would be part of a small group of people struggling with similar emotional difficulties, which will help normalise their experience and allow them to learn how to accept and regulate their feelings

Action in Mind is the leading local mental health charity predominantly working across the Stirling Council area, supporting better mental health for everyone.

We provide person-centred, outcome focused services for people from the age of 18 years experiencing low to moderate mental health conditions as well as people living with long-term chronic mental illnesses. We work closely with Stirling Council, NHS Forth Valley and Clackmannanshire and Stirling Health & Social Care Partnership.

As partners to Stirling’s Integrated Mental Health Service, four of our services form the mental health provision of Stirling’s Integrated Mental Health Service and are provided for people 16 years and above, living in the Stirling Council area, who are experiencing or recovering from mental ill health & related problems: -

Adult Befriending - one-to-one befriending support provided by trained volunteers. This service is specifically for people who are socially isolated due to their mental illness, receive support from adult psychiatry and live in their own accommodation, and who are over 18 years of age.

Counselling – person-centred counselling for people experiencing mild to moderate depression, anxiety or stress.

The Hub Centre – focuses on peer support and group activities such as health & well-being, social activities, developing new skills, mental health self-management, etc.

Rural Outreach Service – supports people living in the rural areas of Stirling who are experiencing or recovering from mental ill health. The service aims to assist people to live a fulfilling life within their own community and endeavours to provide a service tailored to each person’s needs.

Volunteering underpins many of our services such as our volunteer befriending services or The Hub (peer support and group activities) with volunteers offering their enthusiastic support and commitment. All volunteers are vetted, trained and supported during their volunteering experience with us.

location.address: St. Michaels Fellowship 136 Streatham High Road

description:
Grow Well is a Community Interest Company that aims to connect people through gardening.

The Grow Well Community Garden is within Vulcan's Park, Workington (Princess Street entrance).

We meet Thursday mornings, 10-12noon to spend time together gardening using organic, no-dig principles always mindful of wildlife. We grow flowering plants and vegetables and share any produce. We do have a non-activity time during the winter when we let the garden rest, as nature intends.

Anyone is welcome to join us. Come with your ideas and questions. No gardening knowledge necessary. Some of our volunteers have a whole career's worth of gardening knowledge and skills to share with you. Or maybe you would just like to sit on our 'Settle' and watch others garden.

Vulcan Park is within easy reach of both the bus and train station, being about 5-10mins walk from each.

Please be aware we have no toilets on site.

Oxfam is a global community of people who believe in a kinder, and radically better world, where everyone has the power to thrive not just survive. We believe we can overcome poverty by fighting the injustices and inequalities that fuel it.

People become Oxfam charity shop volunteers for all sorts of reasons. But there's one thing that unites them: they're one-of-a-kind.

Oxfam retail volunteers make a real impact every shift and help us work towards a kinder and radically better world, one without poverty.

You can volunteer in one of our over 500 shops or hubs across the UK from the age of 14. Volunteering at Oxfam is the perfect way to make friends and gain new skills, whether you're looking to improve your CV, take on a new challenge or just have fun!

Find out more about volunteering by clicking HERE

location.address: East Kent Substance Misuse Service Transport House

description: We provide sessions for young children to learn programming and coding skills, making fun projects with languages such as Scratch, Python and HTML. Volunteers help the children by answering their questions and helping them through curated projects.

Our OnSide Youth Zone provides a provision for any Young Person aged 7-19 (up to 25 with additional needs). We offer a place to go, someone to talk to and something to do. We operate everyday of the year including bank holidays and weekends to offer the support any Young Person in and around Warrington. With over 20 Activites each night for our Juniors and our Seniors, we need an army of reliable and commited Volunteers. From Sports Volunteers to Admin Volunteers, we offer a wide range of oppitunities to accomidate most people. We must add on completion of training a Enhanced DBS will be required. For futher information please get in touch via volunteer@wyz.org.uk

Through local events, networking, campaigns and conversations we will create a culture of knowledge and understanding around mental health, mental illness and suicide prevention.

We will strengthen the support networks within the town for people experiencing mental health challenges and endeavour to ensure that everyone can access the help they need when they need it.

If you live or work in Warrington and you have a lived mental health experience, then we want to hear from you. We are keen to grow the number of Get Warrington Talking champions so that we can positively engage with our local communities, challenging stigma and discrimination.

We are always looking to involve new champions in our activities, for more information please contact GWT@warringtonspeakup.org.uk or call 01925 246938 or visit our Facebook / Twitter / Instagram page.

As a volunteer at Cheshire Wildlife Trust you’ll be joining a network of over 350 like-minded people, who give anything from a few hours to a few days each year to support our work across Cheshire. 
We have a wide range of volunteering opportunities to get involved with. Everything from getting your hands dirty on a nature reserve, to supporting at events and open days or helping with office admin.

Very simply, we couldn’t do what we do without volunteers. You don’t always need to be an expert to get involved, full training and support is given for all our activities. You’ll have the chance to meet new people, learn new skills and share your experience with others. Being a volunteer with us is a rewarding experience, that's why our volunteers keep coming back.

Please note, unless it is specified on the volunteer opportunity we are unable to accept volunteers under the age of 18.

Set up by local women in 1993, WEB Merseyside (Women’s Enterprising Breakthrough) has grown from a small support network of local women into a vital community based organisation that supports women, men and children through a variety of issues which affect many people throughout their life.
Our Mission

WEB’s aims to provide a high quality service to women, men and children which provides:

Time, space and flexible support to help them regain confidence and self-esteem
Opportunities to explore personal choices to support their personal growth
Opportunities for personal growth and skills development to enable them to get more from life.
Over 6,500 people have used and benefited from the centre since we started, and many have come back as volunteers to

help others gain in the same way. We offer one-to-one listening support, personal development workshops, counselling sessions, group activities, days out and lots more.

Among a number of other prestigious awards, WEB was honored to receive the Queens Award for Voluntary Service in 2007. Out of 253 nominations, we were one of only two organisations in Merseyside to receive this award.

Women’s Enterprising Breakthrough is established as a registered charity and a company limited by guarantee. We work very much on a user-led basis making us a unique service provider in the region.

We rely heavily on sponsorship and funding from other organisations, and are actively involved in additional fundraising events to help finance and run the centre.

Living Well Occupational Therapy is a community interest company providing support to those who live with chronic illness and long-term health conditions in Northamptonshire. 

Knowing that chronic illness and long term conditions affect a person’s whole life, we take a whole life approach, supporting individuals to self-manage, live well with their condition and increase resilience and life satisfaction.

Occupational therapy helps people of all ages overcome challenges and complete everyday tasks or activities, we aim to ensure that the activities that our community want to participate in are accessible and available to them.

We offer courses, groups, advice, education and support to help you to stay well and to manage life, health and wellbeing your way

location.address: Wythenshawe Park Running Track, Wythenshawe Road

description:
Nature Vibezzz is a charity which offers free family focused activity programmes of Forest School, environmental education and practical nature conservation, running sessions at various sites across Lambeth. The ambition of Nature Vibezzz is to facilitate residents' engagement with and education around: the conservation, protection and improvement of our local environment.

 

Nature Vibezzz programmes encourage the practical engagement with and appreciation of local green spaces

 

Free activities include

- Woodcraft (making bird boxes, plaques etc),

- Growing organic vegetable and fruit gardening,

- Promoting wildlife through planting wild flowers, making insect hotels, etc.

- Nature ID activities such as bug hunting, tree and plant ID, pond dipping

- Child led games in local green spaces 

- Fire making and outdoor cooking including healthy eating: snacks/lunch

- Bushcraft skills such as using tools, wood craving / whittling, den building etc.

- Family nature and moon walks

 

As well as the school programmes, Nature Vibezzz offer nature focussed activities for families, the aims of these activity sessions are to;


	Build social contact and co-operation between individuals and within families
	Increase learning, independence and understanding of how to enjoy local nature
	Create a high level of participation among people who do not typically participate in nature-based activities, particularly those from Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic (BAME) backgrounds
	Provide stewardship to the sites and make improvements


 

Similarly, Nature Vibezzz run regular family day trips to sites in London and further afield, as well as night time moon walks at various sites in South London.

 

All activities offered are designed to provide a wide range of learning opportunities; students build skills gradually and prioritize learning of Health & Safety Awareness as well of Nature Conservation Awareness.

Merryoaks Community Hall is the new venue for all community events for the residents of Neville's Cross and surrounding area. Built on the site of the Lowes Barn Recreation ground in 2023. An exciting new venue available for community events, classes, meetings and parties.

We have no paid staff and rely entirely on the goodwill of volunteers to keep the building open to the public.

We help people living in Northamptonshire make the best of later life and have a secure and dignified old age. We provide a wide range of services to a growing number of older people, improving their quality of life, promoting independence and preventing frailty, poverty and isolation. 

We are a local independent charity, proud to be a member of the Age UK partnership of around 130 local charities.

location.address: The William and Patricia Venton Centre York Road

description:
Alfriston Outreach Service (Also known as Alfriston Day Centre) is providing Coronavirus support for older people in the Royal Borough of Kingston. We offer a wide range of services which include but are not limited to :

Activity Packs & Letters, Grocery Shopping and Delivery, Providing Hearing Aid Batteries, Collecting and Delivering Prescriptions, Laundry, Nutrition Support (Hot meals), Technology Support, Befriending and Mental Health Support, Crisis Intervention and Appointment Support.

FUN, FRIENDSHIP, ACTION AND ADVENTURE

Try something truly extraordinary with the Army Cadets, one of the UK’s leading youth organisations. Every year, thousands of young people (aged 12 to 18) and adult volunteers join the fun, friendship, action, and adventure.

START YOUR JOURNEY AS AN ARMY CADET VOLUNTEER

Make a difference in young lives while gaining new skills, friendships, and unforgettable experiences. Join the Army Cadets as an adult volunteer!

We have thousands of enthusiastic and committed adult volunteers who help to lead, guide and inspire our cadets, but we need more.

When you speak to our adult volunteers, they will tell you they do it because they love it. They enjoy the fun, friendship, action and adventure the Army Cadets provide. They also enjoy making a real difference to young people in their community – helping to inspire them to achieve, building their confidence, and encouraging them to think for themselves and to act for others.

Joining the Army Cadets is a great way to meet like-minded people and have fun and in return for your time and effort, we will give you the chance to learn new skills, gain new qualifications and help develop your leadership potential.

location.address: The John Hewlett Cadet Centre, Great Western Avenue,
Forth Valley Royal Hospital Stirling Road
